children.value: At the end of this workshop you will learn how to use the

testing
framework for JavaScript through a series of small tutorials and real world examples.
At the end of this workshop you will learn:
How to create a new JavaScript project
During this workshop you should now have completed the original workshop goals:
How to create a new JavaScript project
If you have any feedback, positive or negative, completing the below feedback form would be appreciated:
We will use Yarn to install Jest as a JavaScript dependency.
Firstly ensure that that you have yarn available:
At the time of writing the recommended approach is to use homebrew for installing yarn:
Firstly create a new directory where you want to run your project:

children.value: Oops, no tests? Let's add some tests!
Jest has great support for React. Infact, if you're new to React, using
has support for Jest by default. We will continue this tutorial
using Create React App for ease of demonstration.

We've been tasked with building a new React component for a movie list.
The component will:
Tell us when there are no movies available
When there are movies available; Show movie details
Below is an example of the component we have developed:
We will write tests for the following two scenarios:
When the Component has no movies
We will not test the undefined / null / error data scenarios.
We will want to install the React dependencies as well as the core Jest dependencies:
Let's create a file for the movie list component:
Additionally create the initial test file:
When you first run this test you will see that Jest will create a new snapshot file:

properties.style: position: relative; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; max-width: 650px;

padding-bottom: 65.6441717791411%; position: relative; bottom: 0; left: 0; background-image: url('data:image/png;base64,'); background-size: cover; display: block;

children.value: You can also see the additional snapshot file within your project structure:

__tests__/
    __snapshots__/
     index.spec.js.snap <--- Newly created snapshot file
    index.spec.js
   index.js
Let's modify our React component message to have a different message:

return
Sorry, there are no movies available.
;
When we re-run our tests they should fail:

Jest has compared the latest rendering and compared it to a previously recorded snapshot.
It has also provided us with a nice human readable diff.
To record a new snapshot you can simply run the test command with the

children.value: Now that the first test has been written, it is up to you to write the second test:
When the Component has no movies
If you have a more complex React render tree that you wish to mock out, you can make use of

to either
change the component's functionality entirely or provide a placeholder React component.
For instance, if you wished to provide a placeholder React component:
When used in conjunction with Jest's snapshotting capabilities, the generated snapshot will be readable:

In other scenarios you may wish to change the semantics of a third party component entirely. For instance if you wished
to change the behaviour of React-Virtualize's autosizer component:
for most of your mocking needs.

For instance, let's say we want to track how a user interacts with our website.
If the user clicks on our banner, we will send a custom metrics event:

For the implementation we will take the given eventType, and interact with the
metrics service with the current time, and a unique marker showing the origin of the
event:

Writing a test is very easy for this scenario. We can import the underlying
metrics API, directly use

, and mock the functionality as required,
and assert that we have interacted with the API as intended:
The tests passed initially, but when we ran our tests again they failed:

children.value: It turns out that the hard-coded time stamp is the issue:

There's many ways to fix this functionality. Firstly, if we do not care about the
particular of the time, other than requiring it being a number:

If we care about the particular value, we can modify our test to include
one of the following solutions:
// Globally override time, remember jest is sandboxed

Jest additionally provides a very powerful module mocking system. However, the semantics
of this can be unexpected in certain scenarios - as it uses babel to inspect and rewrite your code before it is ran.
With the automocking functionality, you can still spy on all functions within a module and modify particular behaviors too:
// This will spyOn all of your module's
// functions by default. This is hoisted
Before making use of any of Jest's advanced mocking capabilities, consider whether a
A mock can be used to simulate the behavior of a real object:
In the previous example we made use of
to retrieve a list of movies:
There are some issues with calling out to the
It's not possible to test edge cases i.e. empty payloads, lots of items, etc.
The website has gone down, and now our tests are broken?
We wish to test the scenario of our movies list being empty:
You can run this test with
you run this test, it will fail.

children.value:
Fortunately Jest provides multiple ways to change the behaviour of objects, and the functionality to ensure that objects are called correctly.
In this scenario we can make use of Jest's
will return a mock which we can configure. By default, the mock will call the original implementation.
Before our test runs we can spy on the fetch call and return our mock data:
We can add another expectation to ensure that the fetch API was called as expected:
Add an additional test for when there are multiple movies return from the movies endpoint.

Below are some examples / patterns / recipes / approaches you may find
useful when developing.

Following Test Driven Development you will write your tests,
and develop your code until your tests are green.

The watch mechanism incorporated in to Jest is very powerful
in this scenario. It can be activated with
It is possible to debug your Jest tests with ease. First add a
The command to run your tests is slightly different:
# Run all tests. `--runInBand` stops Jest from running in parallel.
We can now see that the Jest process is paused until a debugger attaches:

children.value:
There are various debuggers available, however for this workshop we will use Chrome's.
It is accessible via:
At the time of writing there is also support for:

Although test descriptions and structure can be arbitrary, it can be useful to follow similar conventions.
Although aimed at Ruby, you can follow some of the approaches recommended by
For instance, you may like the convention for writing descriptions such as:
to describe functions you wish to test,
You may also find it easier to have one

. This means if you are applying TDD, you can gradually make your tests pass,
rather than attempt to make one test pass - which actually contains multiple assertions.
This can be combined with using
to focus on one particular assertion at a time.
You can extend Jest's default matchers. There are various open source libraries available, for instance:
Or you can add your own custom matchers:
There is also support for colored diffing etc,

If your code is hard to test, perhaps there is an issue with your code. A common testing smell is a test which heavily
relies on various complex mocks, or one which requires many imports.
Jest provides global functions that can be called from within your spec files.

Describe is useful for grouping together functionality that you want to test. For example a
particular function, or UI component. These can be nested as many times as needed.
All of your test assertions will be placed within an
You can focus on particular tests with
If you want to run a specific block of code before, or after each test:

Out of the box Jest provides lots of useful matchers, and you can even write your own!
Some common matchers that you might use are:
You may have missed it, but Jest actually provides two ways of asserting equality:
for matching against primitives, or strict
for other scenarios, for instance comparing complex objects

Jest is a simple test runner for JavaScript. Out of the box it has very sensible defaults, which can be
referred to as Zero Configuration. However, it is also configurable if required.
Out of the box Jest provides various tools that you will find useful.
Expect is a powerful assertion library with various built-in matchers:
For simulating the behavior of a real object:
On test failure it will generate useful error messages:

children.value: Jest comes with an interactive command line which can help you control which tests you wish to test.
There are various testing libraries in existence already. Why would a developer choose Jest, over something else - such as Mocha, or Jasmine?
On an average day, the key distinctions between Jest and $otherFramework are:
Advanced mocking capabilities, out of the box
Inbuilt caching to decrease bootup + overall testing times
As your codebase matures, and your codebase and tests increase in size, some benefits between Jest and $otherFramework are:
available to update to newer Jest releases
Community alignment on Jest - lots of tooling, tutorials, innovation

properties.ariaLabel: using the latest javascript features permalink

children.value:
You may have noticed the code we wrote did not make use of any modern syntax. In particular
we relied on Node's
syntax - rather than the more modern

Unfortunately, at the time of writing, not all JavaScript implementations support this new modern syntax.
For instance with node v8.9.4 using modern syntax will give you errors:

is a simple tool that can convert your modern JavaScript with the
latest bells and whistles into an equivalent form that can run on older versions of JavaScript
that may exist in older browsers:

children.value: For example, below shows two ways of writing the same function

which returns the sum of
two numbers. Both represent provide the same functionality, but the latter is an example
of the more terse lambda syntax available in ES6:
Plugins - These read your code and output the transformed code
There are many presets available, but the main official presets are:
- Plugins to target a specific environment, i.e. browsers, or node
- Plugins related to React, transforming JSX code

To introduce this to your Jest setup, firstly install Babel-Core, the integration support for jest,
as well as
- which will provide access to the latest language features:
To configure Babel to use the latest syntax features, we can create a

file specifying
that we want to use the previously installed

If we re-run the tests, nothing will have changed. Verify this to prove to yourself that
this is true.
We can now make use of the more modern export/import syntax as a result of this change:
Make these changes to your project, and run your tests again.
Babel provides the ability to configure your presets and plugins via

.
For instance, we can configure which environments we want to target:

In the land of JavaScript we often find ourselves writing callbacks, and asynchronous
code:
Jest provides multiple ways of testing asynchronous code, however the
syntax can often be the easiest:

is important! Jest needs to know about the promise otherwise
it will fail to work.
If you have integrated Babel with your Jest setup you can make use of the new async/await syntax.
We want to write a module for fetching a list of popular movies, and add the corresponding tests.
To load this data within JavaScript we can make use of

. Fetch is a modern way of loading fetching resources.
Although

is available on modern browsers, we can make use of a pollyfill to ensure that older
browsers also have support.
Add the fetch pollyfill dependency to your project:
